content.description:
A student is investigating photosynthesis in plants. The student planted grass seeds in a tray with three sections and grew the grass under artificial lights for <math alttext="14" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> days (Figure 1). After <math alttext="14" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> days, the student collected all of the grass from section <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and recorded its mass (Table 1). The student then placed a clear cover over section <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext><mtext></mtext><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and placed an aluminum foil cover over section <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (Figure 2). The student then placed the tray back under the artificial lights for seven additional days. On day <math alttext="21" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>21</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the student collected and measured the mass of the grass from sections <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (Table 1).

TABLE 1. MASS OF GRASS GROWN IN EACH SECTION

Section
 Day Mass was Measured
 Mass (<math alttext="g" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>)

<math alttext="1" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 14
 5.1

<math alttext="2" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext><mtext>I</mtext><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 21
 9.6

<math alttext="3" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 21
 4.2
content.question: Based on the data, which of the following is the best approximation of the rate of growth per week in section <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> from day <math alttext="14" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to day <math alttext="21" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>21</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: <math alttext="3.2 grams per week" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>g/week</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="4.5 grams per week" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.5</mn><mtext> </mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>g/week</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="5.1 grams per week" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.1</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>g/week</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="9.6 grams per week" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9.6</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>g/week</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="4.5 grams per week" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.5</mn><mtext> </mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>g/week</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 5.A: Perform mathematical calculations, including: i. mathematical equations in the curriculum ii. means iii. rates iv. ratios v. percentages and percent changes
